newsitem.title: GERMANY: German FDP's Moellemann wants open debate on euro.
newsitem.headline: German FDP's Moellemann wants open debate on euro.

text.p: Juergen Moellemann, Germany's former economics minister, said on Friday he hoped the liberal Free Democrats (FDP) would openly discuss Europe's planned economic and monetary union at their party congress.

Speaking ahead of the FDP party congress in Wiesbaden this weekend, Moellemann told the Koelner Stadt-Anzeiger newspaper it was high time the party and Germany's political leaders had a frank debate on the euro.
"I think it is good that we will finally have an open debate about the economic and monetary union," Moellemann said.
"It is strange the way the subject is a taboo for all parties. The acceptance of the new currency, in the population as a whole and especially among FDP voters, is very limited."
Most German political leaders strongly support Europe's planned single currency even though public opinion surveys consistently show two-thirds of the population oppose it.
A few politicians, such as Gerhard Schroeder, the Social Democrat (SPD) premier in the state of Lower Saxony, are quickly denounced as populists whenever they raise any doubts about the euro.
Moellemann, chairman of the FDP's powerful North Rhine-Westphalia delegation, said EMU and the high unemployment in Germany would be central issues of the congress.
"Everyone knows the big-mouthed proclamations (by Chancellor Helmut Kohl) that unemployment will be halved is an illusion," he said. "A doubling is more likely at this point."
The party provides Kohl's centre-right alliance with its 12-seat parliamentary majority.
